Other Loads

Snow and Rain Loads: independent of the building occupancy, dependent on location

  • Ground snow load is provided in the NBC. However, since most buildings are hidden in the winter, a coefficient of 0.8 is applied to obtain roof snow load
  • Drift snow load happens due to different roof elevations, thus the snow density is not uniform. Snow on adjacent building could slide onto its roof
  • Unbalanced snow load can result from wind blowing snow off of roof. This could bring a member typically in tension into compression
  • Rain on snow effect creates ponding. Must be considered

Wind Load: independing of building occupancy, but highly dependent on height, shape, opening, surrounding environment, and location of buildings

  • dynamic in nature. Internal/external pressure and suction, uplift, overturning, and vibration
  • Treated as static load
  • Wind load is primarily related to wind speed: mean wind speed, peak wind speed (gust)
  • Higher wind load at corners of building than in the middle as the wind passes through there

Earthquake Load: rare, random, and dynamic in nature

  • Primary effect: violent ground motions generate lateral and vertical inertia forces resulting building damage or collapse
  • Highly dependent on location, self-weight, soil condition (certain conditions amplify loading) and structural system of buildings (unique from other loadings)
  • Earthquake load is primarily related to ground motion velocity and acceleration, and fundamental period of structure.
  • Equivalent static method; response spectra analysis, and nonlinear time history analysis
  • More stiff buildings create large forces because of shorter fundamental period (1st mode of vibration). Flexible systems have longer fundamental period, smaller forces will result. If the structure is too flexible, there is a large P−ΔP-\DeltaP−Δ effect.

Importance factors are used for snow and wind loads. AT ULS, post-disaster is designed for 1 in 100 years and low, normal, and high at 1 in 50 years. SLS designed for 1 in 30 years

Load Estimation

For first-order, linear-elastic structural behaviour, concrete beams and slabs can be designed to patterned live loading. This can be done with:

  • rules for arrangement of live load for continuous beams and slabs
  • approximate analysis
  • beam tables (CDH Part 1 White Pages)
  • structural analysis program

For continuous beams and other indeterminate structures, pattern live loading must be considered to find maximum force and moment effects. Governing live load patterns are determined using:

  • influence lines
  • brute force - check all possible LL combinations with software
  • CSA rules for continuous beams
  • Approximate frame analysis

For continuous beams and one-way slabs, the arrangements of LLs and DLs may be limited to combinations of:

  1. Factored DL of the structure and factored permanent superimposed DL on all spans, with factored partition load and factored live load on two adjacent spans. This creates max positive moment at the support
  2. Factored DL of the structure and factored permanent superimposed DL on all spans, with factored partition load and factored LL on alternate spans. This creates max positive moment within span
  3. Factored DL and factored LL on all spans

Loading Concepts

Beams in normal use are called "in-service". In-service beams have self-weight and load due to use and occupancy

Since the above resistance is greater than the applied load effect, it is safe. Factor of safety demonstrates how safe

  • In limit state design, designed based on probability of failure

To ensure that R≥LR\geq{L}R≥L, follow the following:

  1. Estimate load effects
    • Code specified design loads
    • Structural analysis
  2. Estimate resistance
  3. Account for variability in load effects
    • Loads can be difficult to estimate, and may vary in intensity and location
    • Structural analysis involves assumptions and approximations. Linear elastic analysis and pinned or fixed connections/ends
  4. Account for variability in resistance
    • Variability in concrete and steel strength
    • Differences between designed and constructed dimensions
    • Construction errors
    • Assumptions and approximations in estimating resistance
  5. Define an acceptable level of safety
    • Potential loss of life
    • Cost of failure: clean up, lost revenue
    • Warning before failure: brittle vs ductile
    • Function of building
    • Acceptable level. Based on probability of failures

Variability in load effects and resistance can each be represented by a probability distribution curve:

Since the variabilities could have large effects, it isn't acceptable to have Rˉ≥Sˉ\bar{R}\geq{\bar{S}}Rˉ≥Sˉ. Thus, nominal values from the code are used.

Nominal load effect Sn≈95%S_n\approx{95\%}Sn​≈95% quartile and nominal resistance Rn≈5%R_n\approx{5\%}Rn​≈5% quartile. Then, we say ϕRn=αSn\phi{R_n}=\alpha{S_n}ϕRn​=αSn​. Probability of failure reduced by underestimating resistance and overestimating load

The mean values Rˉ\bar{R}Rˉ and Sˉ\bar{S}Sˉ are most likely to occur. The code specifies nominal values RnR_nRn​ and SnS_nSn​ to be conservative. There are at the 95% and 5% quartiles. RnR_nRn​ is computed using specified material strengths and dimensions shown on drawings. The resistance is further reduced by ϕ\phiϕ and the load is further increased by α\alphaα. Engineers choose (calibrate) ϕ\phiϕ and α\alphaα for different materials to obtain an acceptable probability of failure.

ϕRn≥αSn≥Sf\phi{R_n}\geq{\alpha{S_n}}\geq{S_f} ϕRn​≥αSn​≥Sf​

Rr=ϕRn(Factored Resistance)R_r=\phi{R_n}\tag{Factored Resistance} Rr​=ϕRn​(Factored Resistance)

  • Since steel has less variability than concrete, 1>ϕs>ϕc1>\phi_s>\phi_c1>ϕs​>ϕc​
  • SnS_nSn​ corresponds to service load condition
  • Resistance factor ϕ\phiϕ calibrated depending on:
    • Loading. Eg. resistance associated with tension is more straightforward than for compression or buckling, and is thus able to be larger.
    • Failure mode. Eg. ductile or brittle (brittle don't warn before failure occurs)
    • Member type. Eg. beams are pretty accurate, but connections are more complicated and not as accurate
    • Design method

For example, structural steel has ϕ=0.9\phi=0.9ϕ=0.9 and cold-formed steel has ϕ=0.8\phi=0.8ϕ=0.8. This is because cold-formed steel has local buckling, which is more difficult to evaluate.

Mr≥Mf=αDMD+αLMLM_r\geq{M_f}=\alpha_DM_D+\alpha_LM_LMr​≥Mf​=αD​MD​+αL​ML​. Thus, response ratio MfMrleq1\frac{M_f}{M_r}leq{1}Mr​Mf​​leq1.

Limit State: condition when a structure or structural element ceases to fulfill the function for which it was designed. May be described as a mode of failure, but not necessarily collapse

Two types:

  1. Ultimate Limit State
    • Strength of the structure or part of the structure has been exceeded
    • Complete or partial collapse occurs
      • Strength of individual members
      • instability (buckling)
      • formation of a mechanism
      • fatigue - fracture due to repeated stress cycles
      • loss of equilibrium - structure "tips over"
      • progressive collapse
  2. Serviceability Limit State
    • Functional use of a structure has been disrupted
    • Collapse has not occured
      • Excessive deflections
      • Vibrations
      • Cracking - prevents chairs from rolling
  3. Fatigue Limit State
  4. Fire Resistance
    • Structure must have Code specified fire resistance
  5. Durability
    • Structure must withstand exposure to environment without excessive deterioration over expected service life

Δ\DeltaΔ is typically considered with unfactored loads, except for some provisions with seismic loads

Factored Resistance

Material resistance factor ϕ\phiϕ accounts for variations in material strength and cross-section dimensions. Based on accuracy of analysis method, influence of workmanship, and construction tolerance

For concrete, fc′f_c\primefc​′ is the nominal strength. ϕcfc′\phi_cf_c\primeϕc​fc​′ is the factored compressive strength, and ϕc0.6fc′\phi_c{0.6}\sqrt{f_c\prime}ϕc​0.6fc​′​ is factored tensile strength. Factored tensile strength is modulus of rupture. ϕc=0.65\phi_c=0.65ϕc​=0.65

For steel reinforcement, ϕs=0.85\phi_s=0.85ϕs​=0.85 for reinforcing bars and WWF, while ϕp=0.9\phi_p=0.9ϕp​=0.9 for prestressing tendons. These tendons are of higher quality, with less variability compared to concrete

For structural steel, ϕ=0.9\phi=0.9ϕ=0.9. However, if considering fracture failure (brittle), ϕ=0.75\phi=0.75ϕ=0.75. ϕb=0.8\phi_b=0.8ϕb​=0.8 for bolts - the value improved due to install method changes as well as quality manufacturing. ϕsc=0.8\phi_{sc}=0.8ϕsc​=0.8 for shear connectors, used in composite construction to transfer shear from concrete to steel beam. ϕw=0.67\phi_w=0.67ϕw​=0.67 is used for welds due to workmanship concerns

Factored Load Effect

Both load factors and combinations (companion loads) are used. Adopted by CSA S16, A23.3-04, 2016 OBC from 2015 NBC

2015 NBC load types and definitions (specified service loads except E, 1 in 50 probability of exceedence in given year):

  • D = dead load (permanent)
  • L = live load due to use and occupancy (variable)
  • S = load due to snow and rain (variable)
  • W = load due to wind (variable)
  • E = earthquake load and effects (rare load, 1 in 2500 probability exceedance per year)
  • H = load due to lateral earth pressure and groundwater (permanent)
  • P = Effects due to prestress (permanent)
  • T = effects due to imposed deformations: contraction, expansion, or deflection caused by temperature changes, creep, shrinkage, moisture changes, ground settlement, or combinations thereof. May be permanent or variable

The factored load combination for ULS requires the critical combination of loads to produce the maximum force effect (M,V,N) for design. However, with 1-in-50 probability of exceedance, it is unlikely that the full design values for all load types will occur at the same time

Turkstra's Rule for load combinations: the worst case of combined transient loads occurs when: one load, the principal action, is its extreme value, and other companion actions are the largest expected while the principal action is maximum

Wind load causes uplift at supports and dead load counteracts the uplift. Thus, 0.9 used instead of 1.0. However, there can be exception - wind must be in opposite sense of dead load. In the below, 0.9 is conservative in the left column and not the right column:

Other important changes include:

  • load factor for dead load D due to soil, plants and trees increased to 1.5 because more variable.
  • load effects due to imposed deformations T, lateral earth pressure H, and prestress P should be included as permanent principal loads when they affect the structural safety. H and P are never taken as companion loads
    • αT=1.25\alpha_T=1.25αT​=1.25
    • αH=1.5\alpha_H=1.5αH​=1.5
    • αP=1.0\alpha_P=1.0αP​=1.0
  • each variable load type must be considered as a principal load with the other variable loads treated as companion load
  • companion loads are neglected if acting in opposite direction as principal load effect

Note: read commentary A limit states design of NBC 2015

For serviceability limit state, conditions in structure are checked under service load conditions. Principal laod factors = 1.0. Primary concerns include deflections and crack widths

  • Δ<Limit\Delta<\textrm{Limit}Δ<Limit
  • w<Limitw<\textrm{Limit}w<Limit
  • Other concerns: vibrations, permanent deformation

Serviceability load combinations: see below, with αL=0.5\alpha_L=0.5αL​=0.5 and αS=0.2\alpha_S=0.2αS​=0.2 (snow and wind also include an importance factor for serviceability)

In design of concrete beams, SLS used to compute stresses under service load to assess cracking and fatigue. In design of steel beams, SLS used to evaluate deflection of beam. Concrete and steel standards both have different deflection limits - check before design

Introduction to Structural Steel

3 aspects focussed on: material behaviour, design of doubles symmetric structure steel column, and design of laterally braced structural steel beam

Stress and strain are proportional until the proportional limit. At this point, FyF_yFy​ is the specified min yield strength. This is followed by plastic deformation and eventually strain hardening, which produces an ultimate tensile strength FuF_uFu​. In North America, company provides a minimum yield strength, but your testing can prove a higher min yield strength to use.

  • Steel has high yield strength compared to timber and concrete
  • Steel is very stiff in the elastic range
  • Since it is hard to tell when the plastic range starts, the stress applied at 0.20.2%0.2 strain is taken as FyF_yFy​
  • Highly ductile: ductility of steel relieves overstress in portions of a steel component by permitting yielding. This plastic deformation absorbs energy, preventing brittle failure

The modulus of elasticity for strain hardening, Est≈0.05EE_{st}\approx{0.05E}Est​≈0.05E initially, but conservatively averaged at about Est≈0.02EE_{st}\approx{0.02E}Est​≈0.02E. Strain hardening assumed to start at 22%2 of strain and failure at 2020%20 strain

Property Typical Value
E 200 000 MPa
ν\nuν 0.3
G 77 000 MPa
γ\gammaγ 7850 kgm3\frac{kg}{m^3}m3kg​
Thermal expansion c 11.7E-6 per ºC

For temperature elongation and contraction, we have ΔL=c⋅L⋅ΔT\Delta{L}=c\cdot{L}\cdot{\Delta{T}}ΔL=c⋅L⋅ΔT if it is free to elongate or contract. The change in normal stress is Δσ=c⋅E⋅ΔT\Delta\sigma=c\cdot{E}\cdot\Delta{T}Δσ=c⋅E⋅ΔT if it is restrained from elongating/contracting. Expansion joints are often used, but are difficult to design due to leaking concerns

Steel used is carbon steel for rebar (CSA A36) and structural steel (A500, A529). as well as high strength, low allow steel found in ASTM standard. There are 8 different types of steels produced under the classifications:

  • G: general construction steel. Primarily used for rebar or other components since not suitable for welding
  • W: weldable steel
  • WT: weldable notch toughness steel
  • R: atmospheric corrosion resistant steel. This produces a layer of rust, which prevents further rust
  • A: atmospheric corrosion resistant weldable steel
  • AT: atmospheric corrosion resistant weldable notch toughness steel
  • Q: quenched and tempered low allow steel. Highly ductile
  • QT: quenched and tempered low alloy notch toughness steel

CL. 5.2.2 accomodates for uncertain steel strength. For unidentified structural steel. Use Fy=210F_y=210Fy​=210 and Fu=380F_u=380Fu​=380 MPa. This corresponds to the conservative strength of steel in the 30s. This was also political weapon from CSA, as ASTM steel strength is different strength. It is said that if steel is imported and not to CSA standard, it should use uncertain values even if they are much lower than rated values

Sheet Steeo: steel deck and cold-form structural steel CSA S136

Bolts have no canadian standards. Thus, only made with US specificaitons. By CL 5.1.7, different strength. Design parameter used is FuF_uFu​ because failure mode is fracture

  • A 325M: Fu=830 MPaF_u=830\textrm{ MPa}Fu​=830 MPa
  • A 490M: Fu=1040 MPaF_u=1040\textrm{ MPa}Fu​=1040 MPa
  • A 325 bolts 1 inch or less in diameter : Fu=825 MPaF_u=825\textrm{ MPa}Fu​=825 MPa
  • A 325 bolts greater than 1 inch in diameter: Fu=725 MPaF_u=725\textrm{ MPa}Fu​=725 MPa
  • A 490: Fu=1035 MPaF_u=1035\textrm{ MPa}Fu​=1035 MPa

In high seismic, A325M better than A490M because has higher ductility even htough lower strength.

Welding electrodes covered in CSA W48, anchor rods covered in CSA G40.20/G40.21

Notch toughness demonstrates resistance to brittle failure. Below 0ºC, brittle fracture can happen at low nominal stress, with good ductility above 10ºC. Touchness found with Charpy V-Notch test. See below:

In the above, the material to the left is better because it can absorb more energy at a lower temperature.

Fire protection is also necessary. Yield stress and Young's Modulus decrease as temperature increase. At 350ºC, steel looses strength and stiffness. Fire resistant steel available from Japan. Fire-proofing is more necessary for columns than beams, but beams should still be designed with temperature loads. See Annex K of CSA S16

Large number of cycles of fluctuating loads, bridges, crane girders cause growth of cracks in steel at stress well below yield stress

  • CSA-S16: limit states design of steel structures. This applies to buildings
  • CSA-S136: cold-formed steel structural members. This applies to buildings
  • CSA-S6: design of highway bridges. This applies to bridges
  • CSA-W59: welded steel construction. This applies to wel steel structures

It is important to know the shapes and cross-section properties. See below:

  • W610x101 means nominal depth of 610mm, and mass of 101 kg/m. This has constant flange with W-shape
  • S380x64 means nominal depth of 380 and mass of 64 kg/m. S-shape has variable flange depth
  • C-section has variable flange thickness
  • WT-section is cut from a W-section
  • L127x89x9.5 means nominal depth of 127, nominal width of 89, and nominal thickness of 9.5

HSS sections have different classes

  • Class H: made by welding or other process, hot rolled or cold-formed and stress relieved
  • Class C: not stress relieved

Welded shapes have other classes too:

  • WWF: weld wide flange
  • WRF: weld reduced flange section

See composite WRF section below, connected with shear studs:

  • Double angles: Equal legs back-to-back, long legs back-to-back, and short legs back-to-back. Gap between angles increases moment of inertia
  • Double channel: toe-to-toe and back-to-back
  • W Chapes and Channels can be combined as well for built-up section

rx=IxA(Radius of Duration)r_x=\sqrt{\frac{I_x}{A}}\tag{Radius of Duration} rx​=AIx​​​(Radius of Duration)

The principal axis is provided by the steel handbook. This axis is important because the designer needs to know the maximum moment of inertia for an angle. The minimum and maximum are found at the principle axis

Primary Advantages for Materials:

  1. High strength to weight ratio: lighter weight, saving ni foundation
  2. High stiffness to weight ratio: long span application
  3. High ductility: superior seismic performance
  4. Noncombustible: fire
  5. Uniform material properties (homogeneous and isotropic, certified strength and ductility)
  6. Ready supply of sections, high dimension accuracy, reduced construction time
  7. Easy Construction (no formwork), easy to add additions to existing structures
  8. versatility (easy to make shapes, easy to provide camber to reduce deflections)
  9. High durability and recyclable material

Primary Concerns for Materials:

  1. Residual stress and their effects on strength
  2. Corrosion protection
  3. Weldability
  4. Toughness - brittle fracture resistance
  5. Fatigue
  6. Hardness - machinability
  7. Fire protection - cost
Component Resistance Factor
Structural Steel (FyF_yFy​ 0.9
Structural Steel (FuF_uFu​) 0.75 (0.85 prior to S16-09)
Reinforcing steel bar 0.85
Bolt 0.8
Shear connector (composite construction) 0.8
Beam web bearing (interior) 0.8
Beam web bearing (end) 0.75
Bearing of bolt on steel 0.8
Welds 0.67
Anchor rods 0.67
Concrete 0.65

Lower factor used for structural steel ultimate strength because there is no more strength reserved (stress-strain plot). Before 2000, factors were lower, but raised due to research. Bolts factor increased from 0.67 due to manufacturing improvements, but 0.8 because bolt must be stronger than member jointed. Shear connectors low due to uncertainly. Beams have wearing factors due to bearing failure. Welds are always conservative due to workmanship, and to ensure stronger than member joined. Concrete increased from 0.6 to 0.65.

Serviceability Limit State Condition

Vertical deflection:

L240(LL + DL, SL)\frac{L}{240}\tag{LL + DL, SL} 240L​(LL + DL, SL)

L360(LL only, SL)\frac{L}{360}\tag{LL only, SL} 360L​(LL only, SL)

  • Based on ceiling cracking (plaster material)

Beams can be bent upwards (cambering). This can offset the deflection due to DL, and is based on the length and depth of the beam. In this case, deflection can be calculated only with LL. Cambering requirement must be specified.

Lateral deflection:

H400\frac{H}{400} 400H​

H500(WL only)\frac{H}{500}\tag{WL only} 500H​(WL only)

  • H is the building or storey height. Depends on whether exterior wall will crack. Could also lead to safety issue with PΔP\DeltaPΔ

Floors vibrate. This is traditionally not taught in universities, but should be considered

Design of Compression Members

Column Behaviour and Modes of Failure

Yielding: if column is stocky and solid section, yielding will be attained. Holes are a problem in tension members for this, but don't impact buckling for compression members (typically governs for columns). Holes do impact yielding for compression member, but not common failure mode

Local Buckling: important with large width-to-thickness ratio. Failure occurs by buckling of one or more individual plages (eg. flange or web) without overall lateral deflection.

In the below, this is demonstrated. The column doesn't buckle as a unit (euler buckling), but instead buckles locally. Large width to thickness ratio. There is a sine wave of buckles

Three factors impacting local buckling:

  • width-to-thickness ratio bt\frac{b}{t}tb​
  • yield strength of steel FyF_yFy​
  • Boundary condition. If all edges supported, higher local buckling strength. If cantilever, or unsupported sides, lower local buckling strength

Overall Flexural Buckling: axially loaded slender column can buckle by deflecting laterally

In the above, deflection increases massively as critical load reached. This is dangerous because there is no warning. Like a brittle failure!

Torsional Buckling: for slender column with single symmetrical or asymmetrical cross-section, failure may occur by twisting about the longitudinal axis

  • Calculation of buckling strength corresponding to torsional buckling is difficult for single or asymmetrical section. Bracing is best way to prevent

If buckling happens simultaneously, the mode is called "combined"

Elastic Buckling of Slender Column - Euler Buckling

Several assumptions made:

  • column is perfectly straight
  • Axial load is applied along the centroidal axis of the column
  • Material is linear elastic
  • Cross section plane remains as a plane after deformation
  • Lateral deflection are small and are due only to bending

In compressive, pin-pin element, we have:

M(x)=EIKM(x)=\frac{EI}{K} M(x)=KEI​

1K=−d2ydx2[1+(dydx)2]1.5\frac{1}{K}=\frac{-\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}}{[1+(\frac{dy}{dx})^2]^{1.5}} K1​=[1+(dxdy​)2]1.5−dx2d2y​​

Since dydx\frac{dy}{dx}dxdy​ is small, ignored. Internal moment is M=−EI(d2ydx2)M=-EI(\frac{d^2y}{dx^2})M=−EI(dx2d2y​) and external moment is M(x)=Cy(x)M(x)=Cy(x)M(x)=Cy(x). See below:

In the above, equilibrium is established based on deformed shape. This is used in buckling and nonlinear analysis.

We also have λ2=CEI\lambda^2=\frac{C}{EI}λ2=EIC​. From this, we get d2ydx2+λ2y(x)=0\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}+\lambda^2y(x)=0dx2d2y​+λ2y(x)=0. Solving leads to y(x)=Asin⁡λx+bcos⁡λxy(x)=A\sin{\lambda x}+b\cos{\lambda x}y(x)=Asinλx+bcosλx. A and B are solved using boundary conditions. At x=0, y(x)=0 and thus B=0. At x=L, y(L)=0. Either A=0 or sin⁡λL=0\sin\lambda{L}=0sinλL=0. Thus, λL=π…2π\lambda{L}=\pi\ldots{2\pi}λL=π…2π. We then have:

Ce=π2EIL2C_e=\frac{\pi^2EI}{L^2} Ce​=L2π2EI​

Subbing in slenderness ratio Lr\frac{L}{r}rL​, with radius of duration r=IAr=\sqrt{\frac{I}{A}}r=AI​​ and I=Ar2LI=\frac{Ar^2}{L}I=LAr2​, we have:

Ce=π2EA(Lr)2C_e=\frac{\pi^2EA}{(\frac{L}{r})^2} Ce​=(rL​)2π2EA​

Slenderness ratio is important, as it is an indicator for the failure mode. Could be yielding, buckling, etc. Also, with a large radius of duration, or larger MOI, euler buckling strength is higher. Maximized by moving flange away from centreline

If fix-fix, we have same internal moment but external moment impacted by reaction. Thus, we have:

M(x)=Cy(x)−MoM(x)=Cy(x)-M_o M(x)=Cy(x)−Mo​

y(x)=Asin⁡λx+Bcos⁡λx+MoCy(x)=A\sin\lambda{x}+B\cos\lambda{x}+\frac{M_o}{C} y(x)=Asinλx+Bcosλx+CMo​​

Using boundary conditions, we have:

y(x)=Mo(1−cos⁡λx−1−cos⁡λxsin⁡λLsin⁡λx)Cy(x)=\frac{M_o(1-\cos\lambda{x}-\frac{1-\cos\lambda{x}}{\sin\lambda{L}}\sin\lambda{x})}{C} y(x)=CMo​(1−cosλx−sinλL1−cosλx​sinλx)​

Since both ends are fixed, no slope. Thus, dydx=0\frac{dy}{dx}=0dxdy​=0. This leaves eigenvalue problem λM0(1−cos⁡λL)Csin⁡λL=0\frac{\lambda{M_0}(1-\cos\lambda{L})}{C\sin\lambda{L}}=0CsinλLλM0​(1−cosλL)​=0, with smallest non-zero solution of λL=2π\lambda{L}=2\piλL=2π. This increases Euler buckling strength 4 times.

Ce=4π2EIL2C_e=\frac{4\pi^2EI}{L^2} Ce​=L24π2EI​

If one side fixed, one side pinned, we have:

Ce=2.04π2EIL2C_e=\frac{2.04\pi^2EI}{L^2} Ce​=L22.04π2EI​

If one end of the compressive element is completely free and the other fixed, we get:

Ce=0.25π2EIL2C_e=\frac{0.25\pi^2EI}{L^2} Ce​=L20.25π2EI​

All of the above are based on effective lengths. Because of this, we have an effective length factor. This uses the pin-pin euler buckling strength CeC_eCe​ and other condition requirement CcreC_{cr_e}Ccre​​. See below:

K=CeCcre(Effective Length Factor)K=\sqrt{\frac{C_e}{C_{cr_e}}}\tag{Effective Length Factor} K=Ccre​​Ce​​​(Effective Length Factor)

Thus, we have:

Ccre=π2EI(KL)2C_{cr_e}=\frac{\pi^2EI}{(KL)^2} Ccre​​=(KL)2π2EI​

We then can get average stress of cross-section:

σcre=CcreA=π2E(KL/r)2\sigma_{cr_e}=\frac{C_{cr_e}}{A}=\frac{\pi^2E}{(KL/r)^2} σcre​​=ACcre​​​=(KL/r)2π2E​

The maximum slenderness ratio for a compressive member KLr≤200\frac{KL}{r}\leq{200}rKL​≤200. At this point, euler buckling stress will become very sensitive to initial imperfection. Initial imperfection refers to the column not being perfectly straight (as made in assumption)

By CSA S16, out-of-straightness of compression member shall not exceed 0.001 of the axial length that are laterally supported. See below:

Initial crooked column assumed to be in the shape of a half sin curve. From this, initial imperfection y0y_0y0​ is said to be:

y0(x)=δ0sin⁡πxLy_0(x)=\delta_0\sin\frac{\pi{x}}{L} y0​(x)=δ0​sinLπx​

By equilibrium, we have:

EId2ydx2+C(y+y0)=0EI\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}+C(y+y_0)=0 EIdx2d2y​+C(y+y0​)=0

d2ydx2+λy=−λ2δ0sin⁡πxL\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}+\lambda{y}=-\lambda^2\delta_0\sin\frac{\pi{x}}{L} dx2d2y​+λy=−λ2δ0​sinLπx​

From this, we know λ2=CEI\lambda^2=\frac{C}{EI}λ2=EIC​. Also, complementary solutions and particular solutions seen below:

yc(x)=Asin⁡λx+Bcos⁡λxy_c(x)=A\sin\lambda{x}+B\cos\lambda{x} yc​(x)=Asinλx+Bcosλx

yp=A0sin⁡πxL+B0cos⁡πxLy_p=A_0\sin\frac{\pi{x}}{L}+B_0\cos\frac{\pi{x}}{L} yp​=A0​sinLπx​+B0​cosLπx​

Subbinging particular solution into the original differential equation, we have an equation that must be satisfied from 0≤x≤L0\leq{x}\leq{L}0≤x≤L. We then know:

(−π2L2A0+λ2Ao+λ2δ0)=0(-\frac{\pi^2}{L^2}A_0+\lambda^2A_o+\lambda^2\delta_0)=0 (−L2π2​A0​+λ2Ao​+λ2δ0​)=0

(−π2L2B0+λ2B0)=0(-\frac{\pi^2}{L^2}B_0+\lambda^2B_0)=0 (−L2π2​B0​+λ2B0​)=0

B0=0B_0=0B0​=0 is not of interest; looking at previous, we know A0(π2L2−λ2)=λ2δ0A_0(\frac{\pi^2}{L^2}-\lambda^2)=\lambda^2\delta_0A0​(L2π2​−λ2)=λ2δ0​.

General solution is y=Asin⁡λx+Bcos⁡λx+δ0sin⁡πxLCeC−1y=A\sin\lambda{x}+B\cos\lambda{x}+\frac{\delta_0\sin\frac{\pi{x}}{L}}{\frac{C_e}{C}-1}y=Asinλx+Bcosλx+CCe​​−1δ0​sinLπx​​. With boundary condition y(0)=y(L)=0, then A and B =0.

The total lateral deflection, or y+y0y+y_0y+y0​ is simplified to the below:

y+y0=δ0sin⁡πxL1−CCey+y_0=\frac{\delta_0\sin\frac{\pi{x}}{L}}{1-\frac{C}{C_e}} y+y0​=1−Ce​C​δ0​sinLπx​​

At x=L2x=\frac{L}{2}x=2L​, we have:

δm=δ01−CCe\delta_m=\frac{\delta_0}{1-\frac{C}{C_e}} δm​=1−Ce​C​δ0​​

In reality, the critical buckling load is never achieved. Seen as below:

From this, the maximum bending moment at buckling is seen below:

Mmax=Cδm=δ0C1−CCe=ACM0(2nd order moment)M_{max}=C\delta_m=\frac{\delta_0C}{1-\frac{C}{C_e}}=A_CM_0\tag{2nd order moment} Mmax​=Cδm​=1−Ce​C​δ0​C​=AC​M0​(2nd order moment)

  • also called P−δP-\deltaP−δ moment

As a result, the p−δp-\deltap−δ effect impacts the maximum stress. We have axial compression CA\frac{C}{A}AC​ and flexural bending MmaxyˉI\frac{M_{max}\bar{y}}{I}IMmax​yˉ​​. This is worked out to the below:

σmax=C(1+δ0yˉr2(1−CCe))A\sigma_{max}=\frac{C(1+\frac{\delta_0\bar{y}}{r^2(1-\frac{C}{C_e})})}{A} σmax​=AC(1+r2(1−Ce​C​)δ0​yˉ​​)​

  • yˉ\bar{y}yˉ​ is the fiber distance in the cross section from nautral axis and r is the radius of gyration

Depending on the case, we have the below:

Effect of Residual Stress

Hot-rolled shapes: residual stress caused by uneven cooling speeds. Also caused by cold bending or welding during fabrication and cutting operaitons or local plastic deformations such as punching of holes. Uneven cooling and welding are the most important and the resulting stress distribution can be considerable and exhibits stress risers up to 30% for W-shape

Tip of flange contracts; is compressive. At the center (web), it is hot and there is tension stress. Triangular green-triangular distribution is the simplification. Tips exceeding FyF_yFy​ will yield first. See below:

In the second figure, we know that corners are heated, then reheated etc. due to welding. This will put even further residual stress there.

As a result of these forces, certain fibers yield before others. Thus, the material is no longer homogeneous. General equations no longer apply and the superposition of stress is not applicable.

To accomodate for this, the cross-section is reduced, as yielded portions cannot sustain any further loading. Premature buckling may occur due to reduction of moment of inertia for cross-section. MOI changes

C=π2EI(KL)2=π2EIL2×IeffI=Ce×IeffIC=\frac{\pi^2{EI}}{(KL)^2}=\frac{\pi^2EI}{L^2}\times\frac{I_{eff}}{I}=C_e\times\frac{I_{eff}}{I} C=(KL)2π2EI​=L2π2EI​×IIeff​​=Ce​×IIeff​​

About the weak axis y-y. we have:

Iy,effIy=2t(mb)3/122tb3/12=m3\frac{I_{y,eff}}{I_y}=\frac{2t(mb)^3/12}{2tb^3/12}=m^3 Iy​Iy,eff​​=2tb3/122t(mb)3/12​=m3

About the strong axis x-x, we have:

Ix,effIx=2tmb(d/2)22tb(d/2)2=m\frac{I_{x,eff}}{I_x}=\frac{2tmb(d/2)^2}{2tb(d/2)^2}=m Ix​Ix,eff​​=2tb(d/2)22tmb(d/2)2​=m

M is less than 1. Thus, there is severe impact on weak-axis buckling.

See below for modes of buckling:

For inelastic buckling mode, tangent modulus of elasticity used, but underestimates capacity. See below:

σcr=CtA=π2Et(kL/r)2\sigma_{cr}=\frac{C_t}{A}=\frac{\pi^2E_t}{(kL/r)^2} σcr​=ACt​​=(kL/r)2π2Et​​

Combined, or reduced modulus, can also be used. See below for reduced modulus of different shapes:

Er4EEt(E+Et)2(Rectangular section)E_r\frac{4EE_t}{(\sqrt{E}+\sqrt{E_t})^2}\tag{Rectangular section} Er​(E​+Et​​)24EEt​​(Rectangular section)

Er=2EEtE+Et(H-shape or W-shape)E_r=\frac{2EE_t}{E+E_t}\tag{H-shape or W-shape} Er​=E+Et​2EEt​​(H-shape or W-shape)

Since the tangent modulus load underestimates and the reduced overestimate, EtE_tEt​ is the lower bound and ErE_rEr​ is the upper bound. See depiction below:

If initial imperfection is large, strength reduced.

The below demonstrates the governing failure based on column length. See below:

Middle dashed line in the above follows euler buckling, but the curves below it are determined by the country.

Altogether, factores that impact column strength include:

  • Slenderness ratio (based on unbraced length and radius of gyration)
  • K (end support condition)
  • Initial imperfection
  • Material property
  • Residual stress
  • Local buckling (width to depth ratio)

Since local buckling is quite complicated, steel sections are classified. Those classified as vulnerable to local buckling are based on the plate buckling equation

σcrit=kπ2E12(1−μ2)(b/t)2(Plate buckling)\sigma_{crit}=\frac{k\pi^2E}{12(1-\mu^2)(b/t)^2}\tag{Plate buckling} σcrit​=12(1−μ2)(b/t)2kπ2E​(Plate buckling)

This depends on the amount of sine curves, the poisson ratio μ\muμ, t (thickness of plate), and k (plate buckling coefficient). k is related to the plate boundary condition.

With these different values of k, they are dependent on b. HSC uses total flange width b, while Table 1 and 2 of S16-14 uses half the flange width belb_{el}bel​.

For simplicity, sections are classificied as class 1, 2, 3, or 4. 4 is subject to local buckling. 4 requires more calculation due to local buckling.

Class 1 (Plastic Design Section): subjected with a bending moment equal to plastic moment, and given adequate cross-sectional stiffening, can rotate locally. A plastic hinge is formed. Sustains MpM_pMp​

Class 2 (Compact Sections): can be subjected with a bending moment equal to plastic MpM_pMp​, but cannot undergo local rotation. Thus, it will fracture with this moment.

Class 3 (Non-compact section): can be subjected with a bending moment equal to yield moment, but only on outermost fibres. Once outermost fibers have yielded, cross-section buckles. Sustains MyM_yMy​

Class 4 (Slender section): fails locally before yield moment can be obtained

Classes only based on bending case. For compression, all that matters is if the member isn't class 4. In this case, all members behave the same.

To determine if class 4, there are several limits:

Description Limit
Element supported along one edge belt≤200Fy\frac{b_{el}}{t}\leq{\frac{200}{\sqrt{F_y}}}tbel​​≤Fy​​200​
Legs of angles belt≤250Fy\frac{b_{el}}{t}\leq{\frac{250}{\sqrt{F_y}}}tbel​​≤Fy​​250​
Element supported along one edge, restrained by a plate that is substantially stiffer than the element belt≤340Fy\frac{b_{el}}{t}\leq{\frac{340}{\sqrt{F_y}}}tbel​​≤Fy​​340​
Element supported along 2 edges belt≤670Fy\frac{b_{el}}{t}\leq{\frac{670}{\sqrt{F_y}}}tbel​​≤Fy​​670​
Perforated cover plate belt≤840Fy\frac{b_{el}}{t}\leq{\frac{840}{\sqrt{F_y}}}tbel​​≤Fy​​840​
Circular hollow section Dt≤23000Fy\frac{D}{t}\leq{\frac{23000}{F_y}}tD​≤Fy​23000​

Supported along one edge include flanges of I-section, T-section, channels, stiffeners of plate-girder. With plate restraint includes: stem of T-section. Along 2 edges includes: flanges of rectangular hollow sections, web of I-shape, flange cover plates and diaphragm plates between lines of fasteners or welds

Procecure for axial compression (Example):

  1. Determine classification of cross-section
  2. Calculate slenderness ratio
  3. Calculate compressive resistance

For flexural buckling of doubly symmetric sections, we have:

Cr=ϕAFy(1+λ2n)−1/nC_r=\phi{AF_y}(1+\lambda^{2n})^{-1/n} Cr​=ϕAFy​(1+λ2n)−1/n

  • ϕ\phiϕ is resistance factor
  • AFyAF_yAFy​ is x-sectional strength
  • (1+λ2n)−1/n(1+\lambda^{2n})^{-1/n}(1+λ2n)−1/n is the reduction factor, which accounts for inelastic buckling
  • n accounts for the size of residual stress, as well as implicitly the initial deformations
    • n=1.34 for relatively large residual stress (up to 30%). Used for W-shapes group 1, 2, and 3 in CSA Standard G40.20, fabricated shapes, fabricated box shapes, hollow structural sections manufactured according to CSA G40.20, Class C (cold-formed non-stress-relieved)
    • n=2.24 for lower residual stress (eg. sent back to furnace). Used for WWF shapes with flange edges flame-cut produced in accordance with CSA G40.20 and hollow structural sections manufactured according to CSA G40.20; Class H (hot-formed or cold-formed stress-relieved)
  • λ\lambdaλ is influenced by buckling.
    • λ=FyFe\lambda=\sqrt{\frac{F_y}{F_e}}λ=Fe​Fy​​​
    • Fe=π2E(KLr)2F_e=\frac{\pi^2E}{(\frac{KL}{r})^2}Fe​=(rKL​)2π2E​. FeF_eFe​ based on Euler buckling only
    • KLr=max⁡[KxLxrx∣KyLyry]\frac{KL}{r}=\max{[\frac{K_xL_x}{r_x}|\frac{K_yL_y}{r_y}]}rKL​=max[rx​Kx​Lx​​∣ry​Ky​Ly​​]
    • If Fy=300F_y=300Fy​=300 MPa, λ=0.0123KLr\lambda=\frac{0.0123KL}{r}λ=r0.0123KL​
    • If Fy=350F_y=350Fy​=350 MPa, λ=0.0133KLr\lambda=\frac{0.0133KL}{r}λ=r0.0133KL​

Column Base Plate

Plate area: required bearing area of concrete

Br=0.85×ϕc×fc′×B×C(Concrete Bearing Resistance)B_r=0.85\times\phi_c\times{f_c\prime}\times{B}\times{C}\tag{Concrete Bearing Resistance} Br​=0.85×ϕc​×fc​′×B×C(Concrete Bearing Resistance)

  • ϕc=0.65\phi_c=0.65ϕc​=0.65
  • fc′f_c\primefc​′ is specified 28-day strength of concrete
  • Letting Cr=BrC_r=B_rCr​=Br​, required bearing area is B×C=Cf0.85ϕcfc′B\times{C}=\frac{C_f}{0.85\phi_cf_c\prime}B×C=0.85ϕc​fc​′Cf​​

Dimensions m and n are cantilever lengths and are to be decided by the margin of the plate as well as the dimension of B and C (effective area is 0.95d×0.8b0.95d\times{0.8b}0.95d×0.8b). Although only two bolts are needed for structural safety, 4 are needed for safety during erection - workers could sit on column to install beam, or wind could blow down.

Along the plate, stress is assumed UDL even though it is quadradic distribution in reality. See below:

At dimension m, we see:

Considering the cantilever along dimension B, we have the following:

Mf=qCm22M_f=\frac{qCm^2}{2} Mf​=2qCm2​

  • q=CfB×Cq=\frac{C_f}{B\times{C}}q=B×CCf​​

The bending resistance of the plate can also be calculated using the following:

Mr=ϕ×Z×FyM_r=\phi\times{Z}\times{F_y} Mr​=ϕ×Z×Fy​

  • Plastic section modulus: Z=C×tp24Z=\frac{C\times{t_p^2}}{4}Z=4C×tp2​​

Letting Mf=MrM_f=M_rMf​=Mr​, we can solve for required thickness:

tp=2Cfm2BCϕFyt_p=\sqrt{\frac{2C_fm^2}{BC\phi{F_y}}} tp​=BCϕFy​2Cf​m2​​

  • ϕ=0.9\phi=0.9ϕ=0.9

The other dimension is also used similarly. Thus, thickness is expressed as below:

tp=max⁡[2Cfm2BCϕFy∣2Cfn2BCϕFy]t_p=\max{[\sqrt{\frac{2C_fm^2}{BC\phi{F_y}}}|\sqrt{\frac{2C_fn^2}{BC\phi{F_y}}}]} tp​=max[BCϕFy​2Cf​m2​​∣BCϕFy​2Cf​n2​​]

To control the deflection of the plate, the following empirical equation is used:

tp≥max⁡[m5∣n5]t_p\geq{\max{[\frac{m}{5}|\frac{n}{5}]}} tp​≥max[5m​∣5n​]

Procedure:

  1. Find required bearing area
  2. Decide on m and n
  3. Find required plate thickness
  4. Control deflection of the plate

Design of laterally supported beams

Beam behaviour and modes of failure

Flexure yielding: provided the beam is Class 1 or 2 and is laterally braced in the lateral plan, then the failure will take place by yielding or excessive deformation in the place of the applied loading. See case below:

In this case, the most critical section yields and becomes plastic. The web must be adequate to not experience buckling. This is generally a basic mode of failure if all others are prevented.

Class 3 does not develop plastic behaviour in flexure yielding, as only the outside fibre can reach yield stress.

Lateral torsional buckling: sudden failure occurs by a combination of lateral deflection and twist, the load at which this being dependent upon the proportions of the beam, the way the loading is applied, and support conditions provided. This form of buckling only occurs if load is applied to strong axis. See below:

This is a common failure mode for unbraced beam and can be prevented by the provision of suitable lateral bracing

Local buckling: failure occurs by buckling of a flange on compression or of the web due to sehar or combined shear and bending, or, where concentrated loads are applied as the result of vertical compression. Unlikely for hot-rolled sections for which the proportions have been selected to minimise the local buckling. However, web stiffening is sometimes required under the point of loads and at reaction points. Depends on slenderness ratio. See below:

Other local failures include:

  • shear yield of web
  • local crushing of web (web crippling)
  • excessive curling of thin flange (Serviceability impact)
  • local failure around web opening

These only occur for short span/beam beams, and are prevented by suitable web stiffening/local reinforcement. See curling failure below:

For AC units or ducts, holes are cut in the web. Large web openings require local reinforcement web stiffeners. If no concentrated loads, use horizontal stiffener. See below:

For a fully lateral supported beam with UDL, max moment at midspan. Thus, failure also at midspan. See below to understand the strain/stress variation on the cross-section (assumed to be rectangular) at the midspan with increasing load, increasing the midspan moment. Starts just yielding, then just outside fibres yield, then at final part there is plastic moment.

The lever arm changes as the cross-section goes from elastic to plastic.

Beam failures in stages

  1. Stage 1: ε1<εy\varepsilon_1<\varepsilon_yε1​<εy​ and σ1<Fy\sigma_1<F_yσ1​<Fy​. Therefore, elastic stress and no failure
    • εy\varepsilon_yεy​ and FyF_yFy​ are yield stain and stress
    • σ1=Eε1\sigma_1=E\varepsilon_1σ1​=Eε1​; Fy=EεyF_y=E\varepsilon_yFy​=Eεy​; σ1=MyI\sigma_1=\frac{My}{I}σ1​=IMy​
  2. Stage 2: ε2≤σy\varepsilon_2\leq{\sigma_y}ε2​≤σy​. Section is just yielding at the outer edges
    • Stress at outer edge Fy=MyymaxIF_y=\frac{M_yy_{max}}{I}Fy​=IMy​ymax​​
    • My=FyIymax=SFyM_y=\frac{F_yI}{y_{max}}=SF_yMy​=ymax​Fy​I​=SFy​
    • S is elastic section modulus; I is MOI; ymaxy_{max}ymax​ is largest distance to outer edge from neutral axis
    • For rectangular section, I=bd312I=\frac{bd^3}{12}I=12bd3​, ymax=d2y_{max}=\frac{d}{2}ymax​=2d​; S=bd26S=\frac{bd^2}{6}S=6bd2​
  3. Stage 3: as the load increases, moment increases and the yield zone spreads across the cross-section. Once the whole section has yielded, it forms a plastic hinge. At this time, the section still resists a moment MpM_pMp​. However, the section could also undergo unrestrained rotation. The maximum rotation of the plastic hinge depends on the ductility of the material
    • Only applicable to class 1 and 2. Class 1 can sustain large deformation due to large ductility and form plastic hinge. Class 2 cannot form plastic hinge due to limited ductility

Once a section achieves full plastic moment MpM_pMp​ in the absence of axial and shear force, etc. total compressive force C = total tensile force T. We have:

FyAc=FyATF_yA_c=F_yA_T Fy​Ac​=Fy​AT​

Therefore, the plastic neutral axis divides the total cross-section area into two parts with equal areas. In elastic limits, the neutral axis is the centroid-axis. In plastic limits, the neutral axis is the equal-area-axis. See figure below:

In the above, we can find MpM_pMp​ using the below:

Mp=Cyc+TyT=AcFyyc+ATFyyT=(ACyc+ATyt)FyM_p=Cy_c+Ty_T=A_cF_yy_c+A_TF_yy_T=(A_Cy_c+A_Ty_t)F_y Mp​=Cyc​+TyT​=Ac​Fy​yc​+AT​Fy​yT​=(AC​yc​+AT​yt​)Fy​

Letting plastic section modulus Z=(Acyc+ATyT)Z=(A_cy_c+A_Ty_T)Z=(Ac​yc​+AT​yT​), we have:

Mp=ZFy(Plastic Moment)M_p=ZF_y\tag{Plastic Moment} Mp​=ZFy​(Plastic Moment)

The shape factor is MpMy=ZS\frac{M_p}{M_y}=\frac{Z}{S}My​Mp​​=SZ​. Typical values seen below, with κ=−d2vdx2\kappa=\frac{-d^2v}{dx^2}κ=dx2−d2v​ being the curvature and v is the deflection. In the elastic range, κ=MEI\kappa=\frac{M}{EI}κ=EIM​:

The relationships 1 and 2 between moment and curvature is seen below:

With residual stresses considered, the elastic range starts at 0.7My0.7M_y0.7My​. This is because the manufacturing process introduces residual stess up to 30%My30\%M_y30%My​. Additionally, strain hardening is only considered in seismic design

It should be noted that the curvature and bending moment don't have a completely linear relationship. Bending has straight line, but curvature doesn't. Therefore, at reach of 70% of moment stress + 30% residual stress, curvature starts to increase nonlinearly. It is not proportional. Thus, normal deflection equations will underestimate deflection

Flange buckling

In the above, the uniform stress distribution on the flange (triangular on web) puts the top in compression and the bottom in tension. There could also be a destabilizing effect from the compression force, and a stabilizing effect from the tension force.

The twisting moment buckling is shown below:

Tw=σ(bt)(b2t12)dθdx(Twisting Moment)T_w=\sigma{(bt)}(\frac{b^2t}{12}){\frac{d\theta}{dx}}\tag{Twisting Moment} Tw​=σ(bt)(12b2t​)dxdθ​(Twisting Moment)

The torsional resistance of flange is shown below:

TR=JG(dθdx)=bt3G3dθdxT_R=JG(\frac{d\theta}{dx})=\frac{bt^3G}{3}\frac{d\theta}{dx} TR​=JG(dxdθ​)=3bt3G​dxdθ​

If Tw=TRT_w=T_RTw​=TR​, we have:

b2t=Gσ\frac{b}{2t}=\sqrt{\frac{G}{\sigma}} 2tb​=σG​​

The beam load table specifies the maximum loads for the beam to sustain, assuming UDL. Thus, the pin connection has a maximum reaction of the specified load divided by two. Flexural strength is evaluated based on plastic or elastic section modulus only. Lateral-torsional buckling is not applicable and therefore not accounted for. See example

In general, the selection of a laterally supported beam section is such that:

  1. Classification of steel section
  2. Find Mr≥MfM_r\geq{M_f}Mr​≥Mf​
  3. Find Vr≥VfV_r\geq{V_f}Vr​≥Vf​
  4. Find Br≥factored concentrated loadB_r\geq{\textrm{factored concentrated load}}Br​≥factored concentrated load

Concrete Structures

Buildings, bridges, parking structures, stadiums, tanks, retaining walls, hydraulic structures and dams, offshore oil structures, underground structures and tunnels, and pavement are all applications of concrete. Cast-in-place is made on the construction site, and precast is made beforehand

Structural Concrete: all concrete used for structural purposes (carry loads)

Non-structural concrete: used for non-structural purpose; curbs, patios, architectural, landscaping

Structural concrete is almost always reinforced with steel, fibre-reinforced polymers (FRP). This reinforcement may be reinforced (non-prestressed) with reinforcing bars of fy=400MPaf_y=400MPafy​=400MPa and fu=600MPaf_u=600MPafu​=600MPa, partially prestressed (combination of prestressed and non-prestressed reinforcement), or prestressed. Prestressed is broken down into pretensioned and post-tensioned, the latter of which is bonded or unbonded. Prestressed has high-strength steel strands with fpu=1860MPaf_{pu}=1860MPafpu​=1860MPa or bars with fpu=1150MPaf_{pu}=1150MPafpu​=1150MPa. Unreinforced concrete is uncommon due to the low tensile strength

See post tensioned concrete below:

For the unbonded case, cables are hidden in "steel condom", which prevents it from becoming bonded. In bonded case, they become bonded

Concrete Steel
Good compressive strength, virtually no tensile strength Equal strength in compression (10x concrete) and tension (100x concrete)
Limited ductility Excellent ductility
Good durability Susceptible to corrosion
Low maintenance Higher maintenance
Basic materials ready available: sand, gravel, cement Iron ore expensive to obtain and process
High fire resistance Requires fire protection

When the materials are combined to a composite structure, disadvantages and advantages balance each other out

Advantages of concrete: architectural functions, can form various shapes; rigidity: stiffness and mass result in less vibration; opportunities for utilization of waste materials, such as fly ash, silica fume, rice husk, recycled concrete aggregate

Disadvantages of concrete: formwork and shoring required, and high construction time; low strength per unit weight or volume - 10% of steels strength, with 30% of steel density, ∴\therefore∴ steel better for long span structures; time dependent volume changes, such as creep and shrinkage

For the combined material, there must be structural combatibility. That is, materials need to be connected or bonded together to transfer stresses/forces. Steel bars have surface deformations (standard deformed bars) to provide adequate bond. The materials also need thermal combatibility. That is, the thermal expansion coefficients for concrete and steel are approximately equal. αconc=10×10−6/deg⁡C≈αsteel=12×10−6/deg⁡C\alpha_{conc}=10\times{10^{-6}}/\deg{C}\approx\alpha_{steel}=12\times{10^{-6}}/\deg{C}αconc​=10×10−6/degC≈αsteel​=12×10−6/degC. Thus, there is low risk of damage due to incompatible thermal expension/contraction

Concrete is protection for the steel. Portland cement concrete has a high pH (greater than 12.5). As long as this remains hig, steel will not corrode. Adequate concrete cover reduces the risk of steel corrosion and also provides protection against fire damage

Behaviour of structural concrete

For plain concrete, stress is increased until f>ftensf>f_{tens}f>ftens​, which leads to initial crack. Further stress leads to brittle failure. For reinforced concrete, rebar resists the tension force as cracking happens. Moment of inertia decreases as crack starts, which further increases the normal stress. Cracks must develop to engage the steel. After crackng, tension is almost entirely carried by steel. Failure either happens by yielding of cables or cracking on the compression side

Concrete: composite material composed of coarse grunular material (aggregate or filler) embedded in a hard matrix of material (mortar cement or binder)

  • Cement: generic term for binder. Either portland cement, asphalt, or epoxy/polymer resin
  • Mortar: sand, cement, water, and mineral admixtures, as well as chemical admixtures
  • Course Aggregate: gravel or rock; anything retained on a number 4 sieve or higher
  • Fine and course aggregate is 60-75% of concrete volume, and 70-85% of concrete mass. Can be used as a filler and is less expensive than cement. HAs better volume stability (against creep and shrinkage) than cement alone
  • Fine aggregates range from 35% to 45% of total aggregate content by mass or volume (may be higher for pumping)
  • Mortar content is 50-65% by volume and 45-60% by mass

Good resources include "Design and control of concrete mixtures" by cement association of Canada, concrete by mindess, young, and darwin; properties of concrete by Neville; and reinforced concrete by MacGregor and Bartlett

Strength of concrete is based on the 3-link chain (mortar, bond, and coarse aggregate). Strength is limited by the weakest link

  • Mortar's strength is a function of the water-cement ratio, cement contant, and admixtures (chemical or mineral)
  • Bond's strength is a function of the strength of mortar, size of course aggregate (higher curvature for smaller coarse aggregate means better bond); surface roughness of course aggregate (river gravel is low, crushed stone has rough surface and is high rough, thus high strength)
  • Course aggregate strength is a function of mineralogy and compressive strength of rock. Limestone between 40-240 MPa, granite 110-250 MPa, trap rock 200-380 MPa (igneous rock)

In general, strength of normal concrete is primarily controlled by the strength of the mortar. This is predominantly controlled by the water-cement ratio. Strength increases as w/c ratio decreases. Decreased w/c ratio reduces workability, possibly leading to placement and consolidation problems. More w/c ratio means more porosity, lower strength

Compressive strength is based on testing standard concrete cylinders (North America). Concrete cube is also used outside North America. CSA A23.2-9C7 and ASTM C39 specify testing criteria, including the loading rota. This is said to be 0.15-0.35 MPa/second. Common cylinder duzes ubckyde 150x300mm, or 100x200m. Cube is typically 150mm on all faces.

Cube strength is typically 1.15 cylinder strength. This is because there is a confining effect, which decreases as the length of the cylinder increases.

L/D Relative Strength Correction Factor
2 1 1
1.5 1.04 0.96
1 1.15 0.87

There are several mechanical properties of concrete in compression. See typical stress-strain curves for concrete in compression:

Obviously, the stress-strain are non-linear, shape varies with concrete strength, the initial modulus of elasticity (initial slope) varies with concrete strength, the maximum strain varies with concrete strength, and the maximum stress does not occur at maximum strain (each curve has a descending section)

f′cf\prime_cf′c​ is the compressive strength of concrete (tested at 28 days). ε′c\varepsilon\prime_cε′c​ is the concrete strain at maximum stress. εcu\varepsilon_{cu}εcu​ is the ultimate or maximum concrete strain. EcE_cEc​ is the modulus of elasticity of concrete.

  • Young's modulus defined at 0.4f′c0.4f\prime_c0.4f′c​, or strength at 7 days

  1. Compressive strength f′cf\prime_cf′c​ is specified at 28 days. Testing is done using standard cylinders, and is limited to 20 MPa to 80 MPa without special consideration
  2. Maximum concrete strain, εcu\varepsilon_{cu}εcu​, depends on concrete strength. For design use, εcu=0.0035\varepsilon_{cu}=0.0035εcu​=0.0035. This defines failure due to concrete crushing
  3. Modulus of Elasticity, EcE_cEc​, is determined by testing concrete samples or use following approximations:

Ec=(3300f′c+6900)(γc2300)1.5E_c=(3300\sqrt{f\prime_c}+6900)(\frac{\gamma_c}{2300})^{1.5} Ec​=(3300f′c​​+6900)(2300γc​​)1.5

  • for 1500≤γc≤25001500\leq{\gamma_c}\leq{2500}1500≤γc​≤2500
  • γc\gamma_cγc​ is 2300 kg/m3kg/m^3kg/m3 to 2400 kg/m3kg/m^3kg/m3 for normal density concrete

Alternatively, Ec=4500f′cE_c=4500\sqrt{f\prime_c}Ec​=4500f′c​​

In tension, concrete strength is determined with testing

  • Split cylinder test: fct=2PπLDf_{ct}=\frac{2P}{\pi{LD}}fct​=πLD2P​. In this test, the middle of the smaple is in tension while the outside is in compression. fctf_{ct}fct​ is the splitting tensile strength, P is the max applied load in the test, L is the length of the specimen, D is the diameter of the specimen. For proof, see "Theory of Elasticity" by ...
  • Flexure strength in tension - modulus of rupture fr=PLbh2=MSf_r=\frac{PL}{bh^2}=\frac{M}{S}fr​=bh2PL​=SM​. Test is done in pure bending - no reinforcement, and cracks will form in between 2 point loads and propogate rapidly

fr=0.6λf′cf_r=0.6\lambda\sqrt{f\prime_c} fr​=0.6λf′c​​

  • λ=1\lambda=1λ=1 for normal density concrete
  • λ=0.85\lambda=0.85λ=0.85 for semi-low density concrete (lightweight course aggregate and natural snad)
  • λ=0.75\lambda=0.75λ=0.75 for low-density concrete

In the two point loading test, there is pure bending. In the one point loading test, there is combined bending and shear. Crack will form in between two point loads and propogate rapidly.

Time dependent concrete volume change

Shrinkage: decrease in volume over time due to moisture loss, predominantly due to drying. Depends on the humidity (low humidity, more shrinkage), concrete mixture proportions (more cement ratio, more shrinkage), aggregate type and member size (high surface-to-volume ratio, more shrinkage)

Creep: time dependent increase in strain under sustained load. Depends on magnitude of sustained load, age at loading, humidity and concrete proportions. εcr\varepsilon_{cr}εcr​ is creep strain and εi\varepsilon_iεi​ is instantaneous strain. The creep coefficient, Cc=εcrεi≈2C_c=\frac{\varepsilon_{cr}}{\varepsilon_i}\approx{2}Cc​=εi​εcr​​≈2

If concrete is let cure for a few months before loading, it will experience less creep. Deflections increase over time. See below:

Steel reinforcement is mdae with deformed bars (non-prestressed), welded wire fabric, and high strength prestressing bars and strands

Deformed bars are designed to CSA G30.18 for mild, deformed steel bars. These are ribbed to enhange bonding with concrete. Rarely, smooth bars allowed. Assuming that the compressive strength is the same as tensile, failure for non-prestressed bar given with yield stress less than 500. The elastic modulus, EsE_sEs​, assumes a perfectly elastic material in an idealized stress-strain curve. If εs<εy\varepsilon_s<\varepsilon_yεs​<εy​, then fs=Esεs<fyf_s=E_s\varepsilon_s<f_yfs​=Es​εs​<fy​. If εs≥εy\varepsilon_s\geq\varepsilon_yεs​≥εy​, fs=fyf_s=f_yfs​=fy​

For the steel layout, M represents metric and # represents imperial.

In the above, the 10M stirrup provides shear strength of concrete. The 2-20M bars are the compression reinforcement, indicated by As′A_s\primeAs​′. The 4-30M bars are the tension reinforcement, indicated by AsA_sAs​.

As=Ab×1000mmspacingA_s=A_b\times\frac{1000mm}{spacing} As​=Ab​×spacing1000mm​

Compression reinforcement is used because:

  • reduce sustained load deflection
  • ductility is improved
  • failure mechanism changed from concrete cracking (compressive) to failure in tensile part
  • fabrication (bars at bottom and top, with stirrups as anchors)

Flexural analysis is used to analyze RC members. Two different aspects of studying RC members include analysis (given x-section, strength and details, find capacity or resistance and stresses) and design (given loading, find suitable cross-section and reinforcement)

Buckling isn't a concern for concrete, as the strength is not related to its length but its cross-section

There are several assumptions made in flexural analysis:

  1. Plane sections remain plane during bending (strains are linearly related to each other)
  2. Steel is bonded to the concrete (εs=εc\varepsilon_s=\varepsilon_cεs​=εc​)
  3. Concrete stress-strain curve is nonlinear
  4. Once section has cracked, tensile stresses in concrete are neglected
  5. Steel stress-strain curve is elastic-perfectly plastic

Due to reinforcement on the bottom, the neutral axis of the concrete will move up. d, or effective depth, is the distance from the top of the beam to the top of the reinforcement. c is the distance from the top of the beam to the neutral axis. y is measured form the top

Section curvature, ϕ\phiϕ, is equal to εcc=εc+εsd\frac{\varepsilon_c}{c}=\frac{\varepsilon_c+\varepsilon_s}{d}cεc​​=dεc​+εs​​. It is assumed that dx deforms into a circular element, with radius of curvature ρ\rhoρ equal to the distance from the center of the circle to the neutral axis of the beam.

ρdθ=dx\rho{d\theta}=dxρdθ=dx. The curvature 1ρ=dθdx\frac{1}{\rho}=\frac{d\theta}{dx}ρ1​=dxdθ​. From this, we get the below:

εs=d−ccεc\varepsilon_s=\frac{d-c}{c}\varepsilon_c εs​=cd−c​εc​

In general, strain at any location y is equal to the below:

ε(y)=c−ycεc\varepsilon(y)=\frac{c-y}{c}\varepsilon_c ε(y)=cc−y​εc​

  • Sign convention has εc\varepsilon_cεc​ in compression.
  • ε(y)\varepsilon(y)ε(y) is negative for y<c, and positive for y>c

Consequence of non-linear material properties

Flexural analysis must consider 3 stages of behaviour based on the stress level in concrete.

Between frf_rfr​ and 0.7fc′0.7f_c\prime0.7fc​′, the stress-strain curve is linear.

Stage 1: Uncracked section: applied moment has not exceeded McrM_{cr}Mcr​, or cracking moment. It is known that it hasn't cracked if fct<frf_{ct}<f_rfct​<fr​, or 0.6fc′0.6\sqrt{f_c\prime}0.6fc​′​. Also, fc<0.6f_c<0.6fc​<0.6 to 0.7fc′0.7f_c\prime0.7fc​′. The stress distribution is linear elastic. σ\sigmaσ is solved using the normal equation, except that III becomes transformed so that steel reinforcement area is put as equalivalent area of concrete. This is called gross transformed section analysis.

Stage 2: Cracked section, linear-elastic: the concrete is cracked. It is assumed that steel takes all the force in tension - thus, concrete is neglected in the tension side. Still linear distribution on compression side. Thus, cracked transformed section analysis with IcrI_{cr}Icr​ is used.

State 3: cracked section, non-linear concrete σ−ε\sigma-\varepsilonσ−ε: moment causing failure. Mapp=MnM_{app}=M_nMapp​=Mn​, with MnM_nMn​ being nominal moment. εc=εcu=0.0035\varepsilon_c=\varepsilon_{cu}=0.0035εc​=εcu​=0.0035 fs≤fyf_s\leq{f_y}fs​≤fy​. Since there is a non-linear stress distribution in the concrete past 0.7fc′0.7f_c\prime0.7fc​′, a non-linear analysis should be conducted

Uncracked Analysis

In the case of uncracked analysis, the entire x-section is effective. Concrete stresses are small and linear elastic.

Cracking moment McrM_{cr}Mcr​ occurs when the tensile stress in concrete exceeds the Modulus of Rupture fr=0.6λfc′f_r=0.6\lambda\sqrt{f_c\prime}fr​=0.6λfc​′​, with λ\lambdaλ accounting for density. Thus, to solve, set ft=frf_t=f_rft​=fr​. Mcr=frItytM_{cr}=\frac{f_rI_t}{y_t}Mcr​=yt​fr​It​​

To solve transformed moment of inertia, convert steel area to equivalent concrete area. However. A23.3 Clause 9.8.2.3 permits the use of gross moment of inertia, IgI_gIg​ to be used, which doesn't account for steel reinforcement. This is very conservative

To find the transformed section, we say Ec⋅(As)tr=EsAsE_c\cdot{(A_s)_{tr}}=E_sA_sEc​⋅(As​)tr​=Es​As​. Transformed area below:

(As)tr=EsEcAs=nAs(A_s)_{tr}=\frac{E_s}{E_c}A_s=nA_s (As​)tr​=Ec​Es​​As​=nAs​

  • The modular ratio n=EsEcn=\frac{E_s}{E_c}n=Ec​Es​​

Net area seen below:

Atot=(Ag−As)+nAs=Ag+(n−1)AsA_{tot}=(A_g-A_s)+nA_s=A_g+(n-1)A_s Atot​=(Ag​−As​)+nAs​=Ag​+(n−1)As​

Using the new areas, use yˉ=∑yiAi∑Ai\bar{y}=\frac{\sum{y_iA_i}}{\sum{A_i}}yˉ​=∑Ai​∑yi​Ai​​

Elastic stresses include fc=MycITf_c=\frac{My_c}{I_T}fc​=IT​Myc​​, ft=MytITf_t=\frac{My_t}{I_T}ft​=IT​Myt​​, and fs=n(MysIT)f_s=n(\frac{My_s}{I_T})fs​=n(IT​Mys​​). These are relevant to the concrete in compression, tension, as well as the steel strength respectively. ycy_cyc​ is distance from centroid to compressive egde, yty_tyt​ is distance to tensile edge, and ysy_sys​ is distance between the steel and NA. Elastic sterss is n times higher since steel area was transformed.

With this, Mcr=frITytM_cr=\frac{f_rI_T}{y_t}Mc​r=yt​fr​IT​​

Cracked section analysis

Concrete area is neglected in tension for IcrI_{cr}Icr​. See below:

Service Load Stress

Most reinforced concrete sections are in the Stage 2 range of behaviour at service load levels (load factor is 1). Thus, the cracked transformed section analysis is used to compute stresses in concrete and steel when subjected to a specified applied service load moment, MsM_sMs​ (check cracking, creep, and fatigue) and the yield moment, MyM_yMy​ (capacity when steel has yielded)

At Stage 2, concrete tension stress is neglected (steel in tension).

Analysis is based on cracked section, linear elastic stress distribution. Stress is assumed to be linear. To ensure it is stage 2 (linear), moment is found by C=fc2×b×dx=TC=\frac{f_c}{2}\times{b\times{dx}}=TC=2fc​​×b×dx=T. Thus, M=C×jdM=C\times{jd}M=C×jd

To find yˉ=kd\bar{y}=kdyˉ​=kd, set equal to bkd(kd/2)+nAsdbkd+nAs\frac{bkd(kd/2)+nA_sd}{bkd+nA_s}bkd+nAs​bkd(kd/2)+nAs​d​. This becomes b(kd)22+nAskd−nAsd=0\frac{b(kd)^2}{2}+nA_skd-nA_sd=02b(kd)2​+nAs​kd−nAs​d=0. By seetting ρ=Asbd\rho=\frac{A_s}{bd}ρ=bdAs​​ (reinforcement ratio), we obtain a quatratic, with solution below:

k=2ρn+(ρn)2−ρnk=\sqrt{2\rho{n}+(\rho{n})^2}-\rho{n} k=2ρn+(ρn)2​−ρn

  • applicable for single-reinforced rectangular sections
  • similar approach can be used to derive a new expression for k when AsA_sAs​ is included or for T-beam sections

From static, T=CT=CT=C and M=T(jd)=Asfs(jd)M=T(jd)=A_sf_s(jd)M=T(jd)=As​fs​(jd). On the compression side, M=C(jd)=0.5bkdfc(jd)M=C(jd)=0.5bkdf_c(jd)M=C(jd)=0.5bkdfc​(jd). Thus,

fs=MsAsjdf_s=\frac{M_s}{A_sjd} fs​=As​jdMs​​

fc=Ms0.5(kd)(b)(jd)f_c=\frac{M_s}{0.5(kd)(b)(jd)} fc​=0.5(kd)(b)(jd)Ms​​

These need to be checked if fc≤0.7fc′f_c\leq{0.7f_c\prime}fc​≤0.7fc​′ and if fs≤fyf_s\leq{f_y}fs​≤fy​. This check indicates if linear-elastic or not

Steps:

  1. Perform Stage 2 check
  2. Setting fs=fyf_s=f_yfs​=fy​, compute yield moment My=Asfy(d−kd3)M_y=A_sf_y(d-\frac{kd}{3})My​=As​fy​(d−3kd​)
  3. Calculate IcrI_{cr}Icr​ (cracked transformed moment of inertia). Icr=b(kd)33+nAs(d−kd)2I_{cr}=\frac{b(kd)^3}{3}+nA_s(d-kd)^2Icr​=3b(kd)3​+nAs​(d−kd)2, with the first term based on concrete and second on parallel axis with steel

At stage 3, moment causes failure and non-linear stresses are present. Tension side has cracked. Failure in flexure occurs when the concrete reaches a maximum or ultimate strain εcu\varepsilon_{cu}εcu​ in compression. Concrete stresses are non-linear at failure -> analysis must consider actual σ−ε\sigma - \varepsilonσ−ε curve. The mode of failure depends on the strain in the reinforcement. 3 failure modes are defined:

  • Tension-controlled failure (under-reinforced): steel reinforcement yields before concrete reaches maximum strain. Composite action is still there until concrete crushes. At failure, steel yields first; εs>εy\varepsilon_s>\varepsilon_yεs​>εy​. Failure is ductile: large curvatures and deflections develop before failure occurs
  • Compression-controlled failure (over-reinforced): concrete crushes before steel reinforcement yields. At failure, εs<εy\varepsilon_s<\varepsilon_yεs​<εy​. Failure is brittle: may occur without development of large curvatures and deflections
  • Balanced failure condition: strain in steel reached εy\varepsilon_yεy​ as the concrete reaches εcu\varepsilon_{cu}εcu​. εs=εy\varepsilon_s=\varepsilon_yεs​=εy​. Steel just reaches yield but does not go beyond yield-controlled failure. This defines the transition between tension-controlled and compression-controlled failure
    • In reality, due to strain hardening, steel isn't actually failed, and this is a brittle failure.

See below for NA locations in failure modes at Stage 3 (at Stage 1, ycy_cyc​. At Stage 2, at kd)

Curvature ϕ=εcc\phi=\frac{\varepsilon_c}{c}ϕ=cεc​​. See stress-strain curves below:

The ultimate failure is always defined when the concrete fails. This condition is defined with a non-linear stress distribution over height c and width b.

To find resultant force of compression at failure, find volume under stress distribution. This is the area under the stress distribution times b. To find this, first find ycˉ\bar{y_c}yc​ˉ​ such that M=C(d−ycˉ)M=C(d-\bar{y_c})M=C(d−yc​ˉ​)

C=b∫0cfc(y)dyC=b\int_0^cf_c(y)dy C=b∫0c​fc​(y)dy

T=AsfsT=A_sf_s T=As​fs​

ycˉ=∫0cfc(y)ydy∫0cfc(y)dy\bar{y_c}=\frac{\int_0^cf_c(y)ydy}{\int_0^cf_c(y)dy} yc​ˉ​=∫0c​fc​(y)dy∫0c​fc​(y)ydy​

Since the stress is non-linear, it is quite difficult to find the fcf_cfc​. To calculate factored moment resistance, we assume:

  1. Plane sections remain plane; strain is directly proportional to the distance from the neutral axis
  2. Maximum concrete strain in compression is 0.0035
  3. Material resistance factors ϕs=0.85\phi_s=0.85ϕs​=0.85 and ϕc=0.65\phi_c=0.65ϕc​=0.65
  4. Tensile strength of concrete is neglected
  5. Steel stress-strain curve is elastic-perfectly plastic
  6. Concrete stress-strain curve is non-linear
  7. An equivalent rectangular stress distribution may be assumed for concrete in compression. THIS IS NEW

For the equivalent rectangular stress block, the average stress over a reduced depth (a=β1ca=\beta_1ca=β1​c) is equal to α1ϕcfc′\alpha_1\phi_c{f_c\prime}α1​ϕc​fc​′. The average struss is thus C=α1ϕcf′cbβ1cC=\alpha_1\phi_cf\prime_cb\beta_1cC=α1​ϕc​f′c​bβ1​c

  • α1=0.85−0.0015f′c≥0.67\alpha_1=0.85-0.0015f\prime_c\geq{0.67}α1​=0.85−0.0015f′c​≥0.67
  • β1=0.97−0.0025fc′≥0.67\beta_1=0.97-0.0025f_c\prime\geq{0.67}β1​=0.97−0.0025fc​′≥0.67

Analysis for balanced failure

The balanced reinforcement ratio ρb=Asbbd\rho_b=\frac{A_{sb}}{bd}ρb​=bdAsb​​ is a function of the area of steel at balanced condition AsbA_{sb}Asb​, or the specific area to produce a balance failure for a given section and fc′f_c\primefc​′ Once this is known, a value of c needs to be calculated for a given d and given strains. By geometry, we have the below:

cbd=εcuεcu+εy=0.00350.0035+fyEs=200000=700700+fy\frac{c_b}{d}=\frac{\varepsilon_{cu}}{\varepsilon_{cu}+\varepsilon_y}=\frac{0.0035}{0.0035+\frac{f_y}{E_s=200000}}=\frac{700}{700+f_y} dcb​​=εcu​+εy​εcu​​=0.0035+Es​=200000fy​​0.0035​=700+fy​700​

Therefore, the depth of block is equal to a=β1c=β1(700700+fy)da=\beta_1c=\beta_1(\frac{700}{700+f_y})da=β1​c=β1​(700+fy​700​)d. When plugged into the equations for compression and tension, we have:

Cr=α1ϕcfc′ab=α1β1ϕcfc′(700700+fy)bdC_r=\alpha_1\phi_cf_c\prime{ab}=\alpha_1\beta_1\phi_cf_c\prime{(\frac{700}{700+f_y})}bd Cr​=α1​ϕc​fc​′ab=α1​β1​ϕc​fc​′(700+fy​700​)bd

Tr=ϕsAsbfy=ϕs(ρbbd)fyT_r=\phi_sA_{sb}f_y=\phi_s(\rho_bbd)f_y Tr​=ϕs​Asb​fy​=ϕs​(ρb​bd)fy​

AsbA_{sb}Asb​ and ρbbd\rho_bbdρb​bd are unknown. By setting Cr=TrC_r=T_rCr​=Tr​, we can solve for ρb\rho_bρb​. Se below:

ρb=α1β1ϕcϕs(700700+fy)fc′fy(Balanced reinforcement ratio)\rho_b=\alpha_1\beta_1\frac{\phi_c}{\phi_s}(\frac{700}{700+f_y})\frac{f_c\prime}{f_y}\tag{Balanced reinforcement ratio} ρb​=α1​β1​ϕs​ϕc​​(700+fy​700​)fy​fc​′​(Balanced reinforcement ratio)

  • defines transition between tension-controlled (under-reinforced) and compression-controlled (over-reinforced)

The c/d limit for yielding of reinforcement is defined by CL 10.5.2. c varies relative to cbc_bcb​ depending on the failure mode.

For under-reinforced section, cd<700700+fy\frac{c}{d}<\frac{700}{700+f_y}dc​<700+fy​700​. As<AsbA_s<A_{sb}As​<Asb​, ρ<ρb\rho<\rho_bρ<ρb​, and εs>εy\varepsilon_s>\varepsilon_yεs​>εy​

For over-reinforced section, cd>700700+fy\frac{c}{d}>\frac{700}{700+f_y}dc​>700+fy​700​. As>AsbA_s>A_{sb}As​>Asb​, ρ>ρb\rho>\rho_bρ>ρb​, and εs<εy\varepsilon_s<\varepsilon_yεs​<εy​

Clause 10.5.2 requires tension reinforcement to yield. Thus, yielding is always checked. Instead of cd≤700700+fy\frac{c}{d}\leq\frac{700}{700+f_y}dc​≤700+fy​700​, a factor has been applied onto this. See below:

cd≤0.8700700+fy\frac{c}{d}\leq{0.8\frac{700}{700+f_y}} dc​≤0.8700+fy​700​

In Table 2.1 of the CAC handbook, ρb\rho_bρb​, α\alphaα, and β\betaβ are given for a given fc′f_c\primefc​′ and fyf_yfy​ For these values at 30 and 400 MPa respectively, ρb=0.0263=2.63%\rho_b=0.0263=2.63\%ρb​=0.0263=2.63%

For under-reinforced conditions, εc=εcu\varepsilon_c=\varepsilon_{cu}εc​=εcu​. Steel yielding occurs for ρ<ρb\rho<\rho_bρ<ρb​. Setting Cr=TRC_r=T_RCr​=TR​, we gave α1ϕcfc′ab=ϕsAsfy\alpha_1\phi_cf_c\prime{ab}=\phi_sA_sf_yα1​ϕc​fc​′ab=ϕs​As​fy​. Thus, we have:

a=ϕsAsfyα1ϕcfc′ba=\frac{\phi_sA_sf_y}{\alpha_1\phi_cf_c\prime{b}} a=α1​ϕc​fc​′bϕs​As​fy​​

  • c=aβ1c=\frac{a}{\beta_1}c=β1​a​

To ensure that still is yielding, check that cd≤0.8700700+fy\frac{c}{d}\leq{0.8}\frac{700}{700+f_y}dc​≤0.8700+fy​700​. Lever arm z=d−0.5az=d-0.5az=d−0.5a, moment resistance Mr=TrzM_r=T_rzMr​=Tr​z, and Mr=ϕsAsfy(d−0.5a)M_r=\phi_sA_sf_y(d-0.5a)Mr​=ϕs​As​fy​(d−0.5a)

Over-reinforced failure

For over-reinforced conditions, we know εc=εcu\varepsilon_c=\varepsilon_{cu}εc​=εcu​ is known. However, εs\varepsilon_sεs​ and fsf_sfs​ are unknown. Since fs<fyf_s<f_yfs​<fy​, we have the below:

fs=Esεsf_s=E_s\varepsilon_s fs​=Es​εs​

From strain combatibility, εsεcu=d−cc\frac{\varepsilon_s}{\varepsilon_{cu}}=\frac{d-c}{c}εcu​εs​​=cd−c​. Steel strain is wthen expressed in terms of εcu\varepsilon_{cu}εcu​

εs=d−ccεcu=(β1da−1)εcu\varepsilon_s=\frac{d-c}{c}\varepsilon_{cu}=(\frac{\beta_1d}{a}-1)\varepsilon_{cu} εs​=cd−c​εcu​=(aβ1​d​−1)εcu​

fs=Es(β1da−1)εcuf_s=E_s(\frac{\beta_1d}{a}-1)\varepsilon_{cu} fs​=Es​(aβ1​d​−1)εcu​

Since Tr=ϕsAsfsT_r=\phi_sA_sf_sTr​=ϕs​As​fs​ and Cr=α1ϕcfc′abC_r=\alpha_1\phi_cf_c\prime{ab}Cr​=α1​ϕc​fc​′ab, and Tr=CrT_r=C_rTr​=Cr​, the solution is rearranged into a quadratic. See solution below:

(α1ϕcfc′b)a2+(ϕsAsEsεcu)a−ϕsAsEsεcuβ1d=0(\alpha_1\phi_cf_c\prime{b})a^2+(\phi_sA_sE_s\varepsilon_{cu})a-\phi_sA_sE_s\varepsilon_{cu}\beta_1d=0 (α1​ϕc​fc​′b)a2+(ϕs​As​Es​εcu​)a−ϕs​As​Es​εcu​β1​d=0

Once a is obtained, compute c and check if cd>700700+fy\frac{c}{d}>\frac{700}{700+f_y}dc​>700+fy​700​. With the lever arm equalling z=d−0.5az=d-0.5az=d−0.5a, we know the moment resistance Mr=Trz=CrzM_r=T_rz=C_rzMr​=Tr​z=Cr​z. Since everything is known in the compressive term, fsf_sfs​ doesn't need to be solved for, as we can just solve with CrC_rCr​

Cracking Moment and Minimum Reinforcement

To ensure that there is a minimum reinforcement in the section, three options for checks:

  1. Ensure minimum strength Mr≥1.2McrM_r\geq{1.2M_{cr}}Mr​≥1.2Mcr​
  2. Provide minimum reinforcement As,min=0.2fc′bthfyA_{s,min}=\frac{0.2\sqrt{f_c\prime}b_th}{f_y}As,min​=fy​0.2fc​′​bt​h​, btb_tbt​ is the width of tension zone of the section
  3. Provide over-strength Mr≥1.33MfM_r\geq{1.33M_f}Mr​≥1.33Mf​

McrM_{cr}Mcr​ calculated with IgI_gIg​ instead of transformed moment of inertia may underestimate cracking moment, third option is very conservative, and first option based on mechanics (best)

CAC Handbook Ch.2 Table 2.1 contains convenient values with Kr=Mrbd2K_r=\frac{M_r}{bd^2}Kr​=bd2Mr​​.

  • Kr=ρϕsfy(1−ρϕsfy2α1ϕcfc′)K_r=\rho\phi_sf_y(1-\frac{\rho\phi_sf_y}{2\alpha_1\phi_cf_c\prime})Kr​=ρϕs​fy​(1−2α1​ϕc​fc​′ρϕs​fy​​)

See one-way slab example and other examples, following the procedure below to find max live load:

  1. Calculate slab moment resistance MrM_rMr​
  2. Load effect: Mf=αDMD+αLMLM_f=\alpha_DM_D+\alpha_LM_LMf​=αD​MD​+αL​ML​
  3. Let Mr=MfM_r=M_fMr​=Mf​, solve for MLM_LML​
  4. Solve for UDL

Flexural Design

Design of members considers safety (strength, ductility), serviceability (deflections, cracking, vibrations), durability (structural form, materials section, details), economy, constructability, aesthetics

Concrete joints are rigid (cast-in-place), and thus highly indeterminate. A knowledge of section dims is required. Structural analysis is repeated if the variation of dimensions exceeds 20% (engineer's judgement)

While traditional linear elastic analysis used, designer knows that cracked concrete under service load may be non-linear. Steel yielding plastic behaviour occurs throughout the structure before failure. Exact analysis always open to question

Code Philosophy:

  • design for linear-elastic forces and moments
  • detailed to accomodate plastic behaviour and redistribution of forces and moments

Steps:

  1. Assume a suitable overall depth, h
    • Based on experience for control of deflections
    • Alternatively, use CSA A23.3-19 Clause 9.8.2.1
    • lnl_nln​ is the clear span length of beam or slab, from centre to centre. See below:
  2. Assume cross-section width, b
    • Assume b≈h3→hb\approx\frac{h}{3}\to{h}b≈3h​→h
    • Also could be based on architectural requirements or column width
  3. Estimate effective depth, d
    • d=h−concrete cover−stirrup dia.−bar dia.2d=h-\textrm{concrete cover}-\textrm{stirrup dia.} - \frac{\textrm{bar dia.}}{2}d=h−concrete cover−stirrup dia.−2bar dia.​
    • If we don't know dbd_bdb​, we make one of the following assumptions
      • Beam and one layer of steel, d=h−60mmd=h-60mmd=h−60mm
      • Beam and two layer of steel, d=h−90mmd=h-90mmd=h−90mm
      • Slan, d=h−28mmd=h-28mmd=h−28mm
    • Recaltulate d later whne dbd_bdb​ and number of bars are known
  4. Determine required steel area, AsA_sAs​
    • Basic Principles: set Mr=MfM_r=M_fMr​=Mf​, Mr=TrzM_r=T_rzMr​=Tr​z, and z=d−a2z=d-\frac{a}{2}z=d−2a​. It is standard to assume z=0.9dz=0.9dz=0.9d. Thus, Mf=ϕsAsfy(0.9d)M_f=\phi_sA_sf_y(0.9d)Mf​=ϕs​As​fy​(0.9d). As,reqA_{s,req}As,req​ can be isolated for
    • Design Table 2.1: set Mr=MfM_r=M_fMr​=Mf​, Mr=Krbd2M_r=K_rbd^2Mr​=Kr​bd2. Thus, Kr,req=Mfbd2K_{r,req}=\frac{M_f}{bd^2}Kr,req​=bd2Mf​​. It is also known that Kr=ρϕsfy(1−ρϕsfy2α1ϕcfc′)K_r=\rho\phi_sf_y(1-\frac{\rho\phi_sf_y}{2\alpha_1\phi_cf_c\prime})Kr​=ρϕs​fy​(1−2α1​ϕc​fc​′ρϕs​fy​​). Table 2.1 has ρreq\rho_{req}ρreq​ for Kr,reqK_{r,req}Kr,req​. As,req=ρreqbdA_{s,req}=\rho_{req}bdAs,req​=ρreq​bd
  5. Choose bar size and determine number required
    • Based on As,reqA_{s,req}As,req​, select bar size and determine number of bars required
      • Ensure bars fit in cross-section
      • Check bar spacing requirements
      • May beed to revise width, b
    • Compute actual steel area, AsA_sAs​, based on the bars chosen
    • Check minimum steel area, As≥As,min=0.2fc′fybthA_s\geq{A_{s,min}}=\frac{0.2\sqrt{f_c\prime}}{f_y}b_thAs​≥As,min​=fy​0.2fc​′​​bt​h
      • tT avoid sudden fracture when Ms=McrM_s=M_{cr}Ms​=Mcr​
  6. Check adequacy of section
    • From before, find MrM_rMr​ using actual steel area, actual d, and revised b if applicable
    • Check Mr≥MfM_r\geq{M_f}Mr​≥Mf​
    • Check if steel is yielding cd≤0.8700700+fy\frac{c}{d}\leq{0.8}\frac{700}{700+f_y}dc​≤0.8700+fy​700​
  7. Check serviceability requirements
    • Check deflections and crack control

Reinforcement details: important cross-section reinforcement details include concrete clear cover and bar spacing. Typically, bottom cover equal to side cover.

Concrete cover: adequate concrete cover provides a bond between concrete and reinforcement (to transfer forces) and corrosion protection and fire protection for reinforcement. A23.3-19 requires cover for protection of reinforcement. Clause 7.9 specifies cover requirements as provided in CSA A23.1 (included in Annex A in A23.3).

  • Clause 6.6.6 is for concrete cover
  • Table 1 for exposure classes
  • Table 17 for concrete cover
  • Also in concrete handbook
  • Cover≥Requirement\textrm{Cover}\geq{\textrm{Requirement}}Cover≥Requirement. Requirement is worst case of 40 mm (governs for 25M and smaller), 1.5db1.5d_b1.5db​ (governs for 30M and larger), and 1.5×C.A.≈30mm1.5\times{C.A.}\approx{30mm}1.5×C.A.≈30mm (CONFIRM IF JUST FOR F-2 or others)

Reinforcement spacing - beams: minimum clear spacing, s, between parallel reinforcing bars

  • CSA A23.3 Clause 7.4.1.1 →\to→ spacing shall comply with CSA A23.1 Clause 6.6.5
  • Spacing (horizontal and vertical) must be greater than 1.4db1.4d_b1.4db​, 1.4×maxaggregatesize1.4\times{max aggregate size}1.4×maxaggregatesize, and 30mm
  • When parallel reinforcement is placed in two or more layers, the bars in the upper layer shall be placed directly above those in the bottom layer
  • Vertically in-line bar layouts is necessary because otherwise, there will be interference with the pour of concrete
    • dstd_{st}dst​ is stirrup diameter, dbd_bdb​ is bar diameter, n is number of bars in one layer.b=2c+2dst+ndb+(n−1)sb=2c+2d_{st}+nd_b+(n-1)sb=2c+2dst​+ndb​+(n−1)s
  • s=b−2c−2dst−ndbn−1s=\frac{b-2c-2d_{st}-nd_b}{n-1}s=n−1b−2c−2dst​−ndb​​. Check if greater than all three requirements! If it fails, use multiple layers

Design of one-way slab

  • Design strip is 1m (b=1000mm)
  • identical to singly-reinforced beam design
  • Stirrups are not normally required
  • Specify reinforcement as # bars per metre width OR bar size and spacing

Since As=Ab1000sA_s=A_b\frac{1000}{s}As​=Ab​s1000​, required spacing is seen below:

sreq=AbAs×1000s_{req}=\frac{A_b}{A_s}\times{1000} sreq​=As​Ab​​×1000

Slab reinforcement provided perpendicular to main flexural reinforcement is referred to as temperature and shrinkage reinforcement. This controls cracking due to thermal effects and concrete shrinkage

The minimin reinforcement is seen in clauses: Mr≥1.2McrM_r\geq{1.2M_{cr}}Mr​≥1.2Mcr​ (10.5.1 for beams and slabs) and As,min=0.002AgA_{s,min}=0.002A_gAs,min​=0.002Ag​ (7.8 for slabs only in each direction). Clause 7.8 applies to flexural reinforcement and temperature and shrinkage reinforcement

Slab reinforcement spacing

  • primary flexural reinforcement for slabs, AsA_sAs​ as required for Mr≥MfM_r\geq{M_f}Mr​≥Mf​. Spacing ≤ 3h and 500mm, w/ h being slab thickness and c/c spacing
  • temperature and shrinkage reinforcement for slabs (7.8.3), spacing ≤ 5h and 500mm. Applies when using minimum reinforcement As,min=0.002AgA_{s,min}=0.002A_gAs,min​=0.002Ag​, Ag=bhA_g=bhAg​=bh

Maximum spacing to ensure reinforcement is not widely spaced for better crack control. Minimum spacing rules in 7.4.1.1 still applies but rarely controls. $S_{min}\geq{1.4d_b,1.4CA,30}

To how far reinforcement should extend into the slab, there are several options.

  1. Determine precise cut-off locations considering moment envelope, bar development and detailing requirements
  2. Use standard details and rules (acceptable for continuous one-way slab)
    • See ACI 315R-18 guide to presenting reinforcing steel design details
